title: Business Sellers Should Seek Private Investments, Not Stocks, Bonds for Their Windfall
text:
There is no time like the present to sell your business.
Nevertheless, potential sellers might want to consider putting the proceeds into private investments rather than stocks or Treasuries, said Paul Pagnato, partner at Pagnato Karp - HighTower .
"There is half a trillion dollars, an incredible war chest of capital, that has been put in the last two years into private equity and venture capital," said Pagnato. "That money is going to be there for the next seven to ten years and that's principally to buy middle market sized companies."
Pagnato said small or mid-sized business owners should hire a fiduciary well ahead of a sale because once they start the process, their lives will change and pretty soon they will find themselves "drinking from a firehouse".

"They are not going to have time to deal with their own personal situation and their family," said Pagnato. "They need to start planning at least 24 months ahead of time."
Pagnato added that closing a deal can be the most frustrating part of the process, because sellers are anxious to get out and "just when they think they have the deal cut, things come out of the blue."
Once the sale is complete, Pagnato said the key to managing that windfall is to preserve capital and find enough yield to live on. Unfortunately, the benchmark 10-year Treasury bond is barely yielding 2%. Pagnato said there are better opportunities to find relatively safe yield in private investments
"You can find private investments like private real estate , agricultural financing, farmland, senior mezzanine debt where you are earning 7% to 9%," said Pagnato. "There's a risk. There's risks with everything and everybody always needs to consult with their advisor. But it's not like you are invested in junk bonds."
Meanwhile, Pagnato is far more cautious about the stock market due to a quarterly decline in earnings and suggests investors hedge their holdings.
"You want to be in the United States because the dollar is strong and it will continue to be strong. And you want to stick with importers not exporters."
